history.content:
I've been told that grad schools don't like to admit people who have been working in industry as much because adjusting back to school work ethic (vs industry, which is generally not as rigorous) can be hard. Also, when you have a steady flow of income, at that point you might be less inclined to go back to school.

I think it's still possible to get into a good grad school without much research experience (Master's, maybe not PhD)

——

One thing Prof Abbeel mentioned during faculty advising is that one good reason people get a master’s degree is if they decide that they would like to do a PhD but realize that they don’t have the qualifications that they would need to be accepted into a PhD program.  Doing the Master’s provides a year or two to build out those qualifications (in addition to continuing to study and learn, etc.).  So it might be worth considering applying for a master’s program to give yourself time to do some research that would help with PhD program admissions if you are still interested in this at the end of the master’s program.  (This doesn’t answer the question about industry, but if you would like to try to get into a PhD and do research this might provide one avenue, esp. since it sounds like you have good enough grades & recommendations to get into a master’s program.)

I've been told that grad schools don't like to admit people who have been working in industry as much because adjusting back to school work ethic (vs industry, which is generally not as rigorous) can be hard. Also, when you have a steady flow of income, at that point you might be less inclined to go back to school.

I think it's still possible to get into a good grad school without much research experience (Master's, maybe not PhD)

——

One thing Prof Abbeel mentioned during faculty advising is that one good reason people get a master’s degree is if they decide that they would like to do a PhD but realize that they don’t have the qualifications that they would need to be accepted into a PhD program.  Doing the Master’s provides a year or two to build out those qualifications (in addition to continuing to study and learn, etc.).  So it might be worth considering applying for a master’s program to give yourself time to do some research that would help with PhD program admissions.  (This doesn’t answer the question about industry, but if you would like to try to get into a PhD and do research this might provide one avenue, esp. since it sounds like you have good enough grades & recommendations to get into a master’s program.)

I've been told that grad schools don't like to admit people who have been working in industry as much because adjusting back to school work ethic (vs industry, which is generally not as rigorous) can be hard. Also, when you have a steady flow of income, at that point you might be less inclined to go back to school.

I think it's still possible to get into a good grad school without much research experience (Master's, maybe not PhD)

I've been told that grad schools don't like to admit people who have been working in industry as much because adjusting back to school work ethic can be hard. Also, when you have a steady flow of income, at that point you might be less inclined to go back to school.

I think it's still possible to get into a good grad school without much research experience (Master's, maybe not PhD)

children.subject: Top tier grad schools (for PhD) will probably not give you much chance if you haven't done significant research related work and have on top of that taken time off of school. Master's is probably the more feasible option, but top-tier schools like Berkeley have strict requirements too

It's often the case that CS people on a similar career timeline will go into the workforce and later have their company somehow support their obtaining a masters. Not sure this is the case for PhD since thats a huge difference in the amount of leave time. You might want to consider this if you know the field in which you will be going off to work is similar to that which you would be studying as a grad student. If not, I'd consider doing grad first for the reasons the student answer gave

Another thing to keep note of: I'm not super familiar with applying to EECS programs as I applied to differing field, but people in CS tend to be dismissive of what they call DWIC (did well in class) letters, where your only connection with the prof is just taking a class and doing well. I think I've read somewhere that admissions committee see these letters as almost useless in general (although this is not always the case).

See: https://www.cs.cmu.edu/~harchol/gradschooltalk.pdf

If you want to go to grad school, you should probably start doing research ASAP, especially if you want to go into ML which is a super competitive field nowadays. You have to keep in mind that a lot of the competition for top programs already have first author publications in top tier conferences like ICML and Neurips (although don't be too intimidated by this, it isn't exactly the highest bar to meet).

You can try and do research while interning; I interned at a hedge fund, working 9-6/7ish at the office and then would go back and work on research for 2-3 hours. Its a bit of a grueling lifestyle to put up with for 10 or so weeks though (although my roommate was doing the same thing so it was probably easier for me than if I had to do it all alone).
Or, are almost all top tier masters programs “research oriented” for CS?

From the research that I did online, it seems that there are often 2 types of Masters programs for CS - research oriented programs, and coursework oriented programs. The stuff I read online led me to believe that for coursework oriented programs, having research experience was not a criteria that is considered heavily at all in the admissions process because these coursework oriented program Masters do not revolve around research. I may be wrong, but I was thinking that this would also be the case even in fields like ML, where if you want to apply for a coursework oriented Masters program with a “concentration” or focus in ML it would not be detrimental to your application to not have research experience in ML as long as you had some coursework that demonstrated your interest in ML and you can explain your interest/experience in the classes in your statement of purpose. Would anyone be able to either confirm or correct my thinking that for a coursework oriented Masters program, research is not a heavily weighted “required” criteria for admissions as it would be for a research oriented Masters or a PHD? Any input is much appreciated.

history.content:
Hello!

I am currently a rising senior and am conflicted about my career path. I am currently planning to enter the trading industry in quant research/trading (after I intern this summer) but I am having second thoughts and want to consider grad school and a PhD, probably doing theoretical ML research , (maybe info theory / signals). I wanted to know if it's possible to switch career paths if I work in the trading industry for a couple years and end up wanting to go to grad school later in life? Do people actually follow this path, is it common? Are there logistical issues, like not being able to get recommendations? Do top tier grad schools still often admit people that do this? 
Also, a much bigger issue is that I probably can't get into grad school. I have a great gpa in difficult courseloads, TA experience, can probably get good recommendations, interned at big tech last summer, but I don't really have much research experience. I helped with some research freshman year but didn't end up publishing and it was kinda BS. 
Is it still possible for me to get into a great grad school in the future, whether I apply right after I graduate or after working for a couple years. Or do I just have to commit myself into industry? I could start doing research now but it would be somewhat limited over the summer due to my internship. I would also have first semester senior year i guess.
Damn, life is confusing...
history.subject: Feasible to work in industry between undergrad and grad school?
